body: Maybe we should just relax the check on objects being of the same class in `isEqualToComparingFieldByField`, after all one might say that if you compare fields/properties the actual type is not really relevant.

Actually I expected `isEqualToComparingFieldByField/isEqualToComparingOnlyGivenFields/  isEqualToIgnoringGivenFields/ isEqualToIgnoringNullFields` to work on objects of different classes. After I discovered that they do not I created this request.

I could try to provide a pull request for your preferred solution. (If you believe this feature to be a worthy addition to AssertJ.)

I think so.
Removing the call to `assertOtherTypeIsCompatibleWithActualClass` in `org.assertj.core.internal.Objects` should do the trick.
Thank you very much for adding this! :)

Ok, I screwed up the fix - only works if expected object inherits from actual type.
In your example, if you declare `person`  and `personDAO` as objects, it will work fine.

issue.title: Fixes #178: Add isEqualToComparingFieldByFieldRecursively

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
I created the prototype based on a slightly modified https://github.com/jdereg/java-util/blob/master/src/main/java/com/cedarsoftware/util/DeepEquals.java 

It's obviously not ready for merge yet, but I want to get some feedback if the approach is o.k. etc., before investing more time.

issue.title: Asserting between collections / arrays of different types using field by field comparator is unconvinient.

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

body: This is a super old issue, but I just want to say that this feature continues to be really useful, as does AssertJ in general. Thanks all!
Just for reference, here's how to do it in recent version https://assertj.github.io/doc/#assertj-core-recursive-comparison-strict
